The Board of Directors of JPMorgan Chase & Co. (NYSE: JPM) authorized a share repurchase program on March 18, 2011. Under the program, the company will repurchase up to $15 billion worth of its common stock. The company will issue these repurchased shares for employee stock-based incentive awards. The Federal Reserve has approved utilization of up to $8 billion in 2011. The timing of common stock purchases and the exact number of shares purchased through the repurchase authorization will depend on various factors, including market conditions, the company's capital position, internal capital generation, and organic investment opportunities. The new repurchase program does not include specific price targets, may be executed through open market purchases or privately negotiated transactions, including utilizing Rule 10b5-1 programs, and may be suspended at any time.

The Board of Directors of Citigroup, Inc. (NYSE:C) authorized a share repurchase program on April 25, 2013. Under the program, Citigroup will repurchase up to $1.2 billion worth of its shares. Repurchases may be effected from time to time through open market purchases, trading plans established in accordance with U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission rules or other means, depending on satisfactory market conditions, applicable legal requirements and other factors. Repurchased shares will be held as treasury stock. The program does not obligate Citi to repurchase any particular amount of common stock, and it may be suspended at any time at Citi's discretion. The plan is part of the planned capital actions included by Citi in its 2013 Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review (CCAR) and is intended to offset estimated dilution created by Citi's annual incentive compensation grants. The plan will be valid until the first quarter of 2014.

The Board of Directors of Fifth Third Bancorp (NasdaqGS:FITB) authorized a share repurchase program on April 23, 2012. This plan is a renewal of plan announced on May 21, 2007 for 30,000,000 shares which was suspended on January 28, 2009, on account of entering into capital purchase agreement. Under the agreement with the U.S. Treasury, Fifth Third Bancorp is restricted to repurchases shares until the earlier of December 31, 2011 or the date upon which the Series F senior preferred shares are redeemed in whole or transferred to an unaffiliated third party. Till suspension, Fifth Third Bancorp repurchased 10,798,482 shares for $441.07 million and has 19,201,518 shares remaining as of April 23, 2012. Under the renewed plan, the company entered into an ASR transaction with Goldman, Sachs & Co. pursuant to which Fifth Third will purchase approximately $75 million of its outstanding common stock. Fifth Third will pay $75 million to Goldman on April 26, 2012 and expects to receive a substantial majority of the shares underlying the Repurchase Agreement by April 26, 2012. The actual number of shares of Fifth Third common stock to be delivered by Goldman will be based generally on a discount to the average daily volume-weighted average prices of Fifth Third’s common stock during the term of the Repurchase Agreement. At settlement, Goldman may be obligated to deliver additional shares of Fifth Third’s common stock to Fifth Third, or Fifth Third may be obligated to make a delivery of common stock or a payment of cash to Goldman at Fifth Third’s election. Fifth Third expects the settlement of the transaction to occur on or before July 26, 2012. The repurchase agreement is subject to certain customary adjustments and termination provisions. In addition, upon the occurrence of certain extraordinary events, Goldman is entitled to terminate the agreement, in which case Fifth Third may receive fewer shares of its common stock than expected.

The Board of Directors of Fifth Third Bancorp (NasdaqGS:FITB) authorized a share repurchase program on August 21, 2012. Under the program, the company will repurchase up to 100,000,000 shares. The shares will be repurchased in the open market or in privately negotiated transactions and to utilize any derivative or similar instrument to effect the repurchases including Rule 10b5-1 programs without limitation, accelerated share repurchase contracts, equity forward transactions, equity option transactions, equity swap transactions, cap transactions, collar transactions, floor transactions or other similar transactions or any combination of the foregoing transactions. As part of the authorization, the company may enter into a contract with counterparty in the near term to repurchase up to $350 million worth of its shares. The company plans to make repurchases worth $600 million through the first quarter of 2013, in addition to any incremental repurchases related to any after-tax gains from the sale of Vantiv, Inc. stock. The program does not have an expiration date and does not include specific price targets, and may be suspended at any time.
